title: Velocity Analysis: The Cost of Speed?
text:
When the pitch clock forced pitchers to work faster, simple physiology suggested they should throw slower to conserve energy.
They didn’t.
Instead, despite having 25% less recovery time, the league’s most fragile aces continued to throw max-effort fastballs. This created a “Red Zone”—a state of constant fatigue without a drop in intensity.

2. The Refusal to Slow Down
The chart below tracks 22 elite pitchers who suffered major arm injuries in 2023. We compared their median fastball velocity in the year they got hurt (Red) versus the year prior (Blue).
Key Takeaway: Look how many Red dots are to the right of the Blue dots. Even as their bodies were breaking down, they were throwing harder.

3. Under the Microscope
Averages can hide the truth. To understand the strain on these arms, we need to look at the consistency of their pitches.
Use the tool below to inspect the Velocity Distribution of any injured pitcher.
How to read this chart The Box: Shows the “normal range” of their fastball.
The Black Diamond: Represents their Median velocity.
The Dots: Individual pitches.
Select a pitcher (e.g., Jacob deGrom or Felix Bautista) to begin investigation:

Conclusion
The data suggests a dangerous correlation: as the clock sped up the game, pitchers refused to slow down their fastballs. The result was a generation of arms pushed beyond their physiological limit.

title: The Clock: A Radical Shift
text:
In 2023, MLB didn’t just ask pitchers to work faster—they fundamentally changed the rhythm of the sport.
The New Rules 15 Seconds: Time allowed between pitches (Bases Empty).
20 Seconds: Time allowed between pitches (Runners On).
The Penalty: Automatic Ball for the pitcher.
The goal was to eliminate “dead time.” It worked. But it also eliminated recovery time.

title: The Clock: A Radical Shift
text:
3. The Human Cost
This change wasn’t just aesthetic; it was physiological. Pitchers were still throwing max effort (99+ MPH), but with 25% less rest.
“When you make the game go faster, your form just gets fatigued faster. It’s simple science. You’re going to see more injuries.”
— Max Scherzer, 3x Cy Young Winner
By the Numbers
We saw a clear correlation between the new pace and the health of pitchers’ elbows.

title: Project: The Cost of Speed
text:
The Question
In 2023, Major League Baseball introduced the most radical rule change in the sport’s history: The Pitch Clock.
The goal was simple: eliminate dead time and make the game more exciting. By that metric, it was a massive success. Games were shorter, crisper, and more action-packed.
But there was a hidden variable. As the pace quickened, pitchers were forced to recover in seconds rather than minutes. Yet, they refused to sacrifice velocity. This project investigates the physiological cost of that decision.
